output: A variable is like a labeled box where you store something. In Python: x = 5 means you put 5 into box x.
A loop is like checking each item on your grocery list one by one. Code repeats until done.
A function is like a vending machine: you give input, it performs work, you get output.
You can't combine string and number. Convert using str(20) or use f'Age: {20}'.
A class is a blueprint for creating objects—like a recipe for cookies.
Inheritance is like a child inheriting traits from parents. A class gets properties from another class.
An array is like a row of lockers—each has a fixed position and holds one item.
An API is like a waiter: it takes your request to the kitchen (server) and brings food (data).
SELECT is like choosing specific items from a shelf. SELECT name FROM students picks only the names.
Update is like a heartbeat—runs every frame and keeps checking game logic.
Variables are storage containers. In C#: int age = 20; stores 20 in 'age'.
A dict is like a real dictionary: look up a word (key) to get a meaning (value).
ArrayList is like a backpack that expands automatically when you add items.
You can't assign a string to an int. Use int x = 5; or change type to String.
Encapsulation is like locking valuables in a box so only you have the key—controls data access.
Polymorphism is like pressing a 'start' button on different machines—they behave differently.
A commit is like taking a snapshot of your project at a moment in time.
A branch is like a parallel universe where you make changes without affecting the main world.
Time complexity measures how slow things get as data grows—like more people in a line.
O(n) means time grows proportionally with input—like checking each paper in a stack.
A stack is a pile of plates. You add/remove from the top (LIFO).
A queue is like a line at the bank (FIFO). First in, first out.
Recursion is like standing between two mirrors—process repeats inside itself.
Index 3 doesn't exist. Use list[2] or ensure index is valid.
Try/catch is like wearing a helmet. If something dangerous happens, you're protected.
Exceptions are runtime errors. You can catch them using try/except to prevent crashes.
Hashing is like turning a word into a unique locker number for quick access.
A LinkedList is like a treasure map: each node points to the next location.
An HTTP request is like sending a mail letter asking for information.
REST is like a restaurant menu: standard ways to order and receive data.
JS variables are containers. let age = 20 stores 20 in age.
const is like super-glue—you cannot change the variable once set.
JS loops repeat tasks like checking each box in a row.

input: Fix JS error: console.log(name); let name='A';
output: Variable used before declared. Move console.log below the declaration.
A callback is like leaving your number so someone calls when they finish a task.
A promise is like ordering food delivery—you wait for it to complete later.
async/await is waiting politely for something to finish before continuing.
JSON is like a digital form that stores key-value pairs.
Frontend is what users see. Backend is the kitchen doing the work.
DOM is like a family tree of webpage elements.
Rigidbody adds physics—like giving your object real-world weight.
Collisions are like two objects bumping in real life; colliders detect contact.
Means you are trying to use something that hasn't been assigned yet.
It's like GPS coordinates of an object in your scene.
Update is frame-based. FixedUpdate is physics-based at fixed intervals.
Coroutines are like pauses in your code without stopping everything else.
DeltaTime is the time between frames—helps smooth movement.
Prefabs are templates for reusable objects—like cookie cutters.
It shows private variables in Inspector—like making hidden storage visible.
Loading scenes is like switching rooms in a building.
A table is a grid of data like a spreadsheet.
A primary key is like a unique student ID number.
Foreign keys are like linking student ID to course records.
JOIN is merging information like combining name list with grade list.
WHERE filters results—like searching for only students older than 20.
ORDER BY is sorting results like arranging books alphabetically.
INSERT adds new rows—like adding a new entry to a logbook.
DELETE removes rows—like erasing a line from a notebook.
UPDATE modifies existing data—like correcting a misspelled name.
SQL injection is like letting someone rewrite your entire database form—dangerous.
ML is teaching computers using examples instead of instructions.
Dataset is a collection of examples the model learns from.
Training is learning. Testing checks performance on new examples.
Overfitting is like memorizing the answer key instead of learning concepts.
A neural network is like a network of neurons passing signals.
Activation function is like a decision switch—should this neuron fire?
Gradient descent is like walking downhill to find the lowest valley.
One epoch is one full pass through the dataset.
Classification picks categories. Regression predicts numbers.
Use dropout, regularization, or more data to prevent memorizing.
Enums are like predefined labels—Monday, Tuesday, etc.
Switch is like a multi-lane road directing traffic based on value.
Boolean logic is true/false decisions like yes/no choices.
AND means both must be true. OR means at least one is true.
A pointer is like a house address pointing to where data lives.
Pass by value gives a copy—like photocopying a document.
Pass by reference gives directions to the original document.
Stack is organized like plates. Heap is like a messy attic with dynamic allocation.
File I/O is reading and writing files like opening and saving documents.
Threads are like multiple workers doing tasks simultaneously.

input: Explain APIs using a restaurant analogy.
output: API = waiter, server = kitchen, response = food served.
GET means 'give me information'—like asking for the menu.
POST sends new data—like filling a form and submitting it.
Cookies are small memory notes websites store on your browser.
Session is a temporary record of who you are while browsing.
Token is like a digital entry pass for secure access.
Rate limiting is like allowing only a certain number of requests per minute.
WebSockets provide live communication—like a phone call instead of letters.
Cloud storage is like renting space in someone else's big computer.
Serverless means you don't manage servers—like renting a chef instead of a kitchen.
